lead_sponsor.agency: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS)

clinical_study.source: National Institutes of Health Clinical Center (CC)

brief_summary.textblock:
PEGS BackgroundPEGS Phenotype-by-Genotype Beginnings
The Personalized Environment and Genes Study (PEGS) aims to provide a resource for environmental health translational research by examining gene-environment interactions in health and disease. The PEGS started in 2005 as a phenotype-by-genotype registry of participants who had donated DNA samples, and who had agreed to be contacted for follow-up clinical translational studies based on their DNA genotypes. At the time, the only information available was a participant s age, sex, race, and ethnicity. Further phenotyping of a participant and/or any biospecimens obtained were investigated during a follow-up translational clinical study on participants recruited based on their genotype (hence phenotype-by-genotype) and the PEGS was the first recruit-by- genotype study at the NIH.1Following a period focused on recruiting approximately 15,000 participants to enable genotyping of rare (approximately 1% minor allele frequency) single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the PEGS Consortium Project was undertaken in 2010- 2011 to examine, using the DNA of nearly 4,000 participants ( the PEGS 4000 ), approximately 700 SNPs in approximately 80 environmental response genes that work in concert with environmental exposures to elicit a phenotype.2Several clinical follow-up studies, genotype-phenotype association studies, and publications have resulted from the PEGS Consortium Project.
PEGS Recruiting by Genotype, Phenotype, and/or Exposure
To expand phenotype information available to researchers, between 2013-2014, the PEGS Health and Exposure Questionnaire was administered and has had responses from approximately 9,000 participants. This has proven to be a great resource for genotype-phenotype association studies and the protocol was amended to allow disease and exposure specific recruitment.
PEGS Aims
The goal of the PEGS is to provide a resource for environmental health translational research by examining gene-environment interactions in health and disease by the following three aims:
Incorporate information of individuals for environmental health translational research through multiple data sources through a personalized/precision medicine based approach
Extend the PEGS as a resource to both intramural and extramural investigators through collaborations and providing accessible databases
Engage as a longitudinal study taking advantage of cross-sectional information already obtained
PEGS Aim 1: PEGS as a Personalized/Precision Medicine Based ResourcePEGS Population-based Resource Beginnings
The PEGS started out as a population-based resource where investigators could access participants based on genotypes for further clinical/translational studies. The idea of using the cohort for population-based studies fully emerged after approximately 9,000 participants provided phenotype and some exposure data between 2013-2014. Genotype-phenotype association studies began in earnest at that time through the NIEHS PEGS Laboratory and the ability of enabling studies of larger population groups within the PEGS began to emerge. A second population-based questionnaire was given to participants in early 2017 to study the external and internal exposomes . After the initial web-based only effort, approximately 3,000 participants have completed the two-part survey. Plans have also started to take advantage of the prospective nature of the PEGS and the advantages of a longitudinal study over a cross- sectional one in studying gene-environment interactions (see PEGS Aim 3: PEGS as a Longitudinal Study below). However, the interest of most investigators has focused on sub- groups of the PEGS based on questionnaire answers such as asthmatics, those with Crohn s and other auto-immune diseases, smokers, black cohosh users, etc. A major utility of the PEGS has also been its ability to provide control participants for study groups of interest. For example, several groups have undertaken projects to genotype participants DNA for polymorphisms in genes that when placed in transgenic mice have given phenotypes (such as diabetes) with an interest in finding a milder phenotype (such as insulin resistance) in participants with the polymorphism. In addition, investigators prefer participants who are able to come in to the NIEHS Clinical Research Unit and the focus in recruitment for these studies is often on PEGS participants who live within 100 miles of Research Triangle Park, NC. Hence there are limitations for the PEGS as a strictly population-based cohort for studies, and a great interest in specific groups of patients which can augment an investigator s need for specific groups of patients based on an individual s genotype, phenotype, and external and internal exposome/exposures to pursue the investigator-driven environmental health translational research.
Personalized/Precision Med...

detailed_description.textblock:
PEGS BackgroundPEGS Phenotype-by-Genotype Beginnings
The Personalized Environment and Genes Study (PEGS) aims to provide a resource for environmental health translational research by examining gene-environment interactions in health and disease. The PEGS started in 2005 as a phenotype-by-genotype registry of participants who had donated DNA samples, and who had agreed to be contacted for follow-up clinical translational studies based on their DNA genotypes. At the time, the only information available was a participant s age, sex, race, and ethnicity. Further phenotyping of a participant and/or any biospecimens obtained were investigated during a follow-up translational clinical study on participants recruited based on their genotype (hence phenotype-by-genotype) and the PEGS was the first recruit-by- genotype study at the NIH.1Following a period focused on recruiting approximately 15,000 participants to enable genotyping of rare (approximately 1% minor allele frequency) single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the PEGS Consortium Project was undertaken in 2010- 2011 to examine, using the DNA of nearly 4,000 participants ( the PEGS 4000 ), approximately 700 SNPs in approximately 80 environmental response genes that work in concert with environmental exposures to elicit a phenotype.2Several clinical follow-up studies, genotype-phenotype association studies, and publications have resulted from the PEGS Consortium Project.
PEGS Recruiting by Genotype, Phenotype, and/or Exposure
To expand phenotype information available to researchers, between 2013-2014, the PEGS Health and Exposure Questionnaire was administered and has had responses from approximately 9,000 participants. This has proven to be a great resource for genotype-phenotype association studies and the protocol was amended to allow disease and exposure specific recruitment.
PEGS Aims
The goal of the PEGS is to provide a resource for environmental health translational research by examining gene-environment interactions in health and disease by the following three aims:
Incorporate information of individuals for environmental health translational research through multiple data sources through a personalized/precision medicine based approach
Extend the PEGS as a resource to both intramural and extramural investigators through collaborations and providing accessible databases
Engage as a longitudinal study taking advantage of cross-sectional information already obtained
PEGS Aim 1: PEGS as a Personalized/Precision Medicine Based ResourcePEGS Population-based Resource Beginnings
The PEGS started out as a population-based resource where investigators could access participants based on genotypes for further clinical/translational studies. The idea of using the cohort for population-based studies fully emerged after approximately 9,000 participants provided phenotype and some exposure data between 2013-2014. Genotype-phenotype association studies began in earnest at that time through the NIEHS PEGS Laboratory and the ability of enabling studies of larger population groups within the PEGS began to emerge. A second population-based questionnaire was given to participants in early 2017 to study the external and internal exposomes . After the initial web-based only effort, approximately 3,000 participants have completed the two-part survey. Plans have also started to take advantage of the prospective nature of the PEGS and the advantages of a longitudinal study over a cross- sectional one in studying gene-environment interactions (see PEGS Aim 3: PEGS as a Longitudinal Study below). However, the interest of most investigators has focused on sub- groups of the PEGS based on questionnaire answers such as asthmatics, those with Crohn s and other auto-immune diseases, smokers, black cohosh users, etc. A major utility of the PEGS has also been its ability to provide control participants for study groups of interest. For example, several groups have undertaken projects to genotype participants DNA for polymorphisms in genes that when placed in transgenic mice have given phenotypes (such as diabetes) with an interest in finding a milder phenotype (such as insulin resistance) in participants with the polymorphism. In addition, investigators prefer participants who are able to come in to the NIEHS Clinical Research Unit and the focus in recruitment for these studies is often on PEGS participants who live within 100 miles of Research Triangle Park, NC. Hence there are limitations for the PEGS as a strictly population-based cohort for studies, and a great interest in specific groups of patients which can augment an investigator s need for specific groups of patients based on an individual s genotype, phenotype, and external and internal exposome/exposures to pursue the investigator-driven environmental health translational research.
Personalized/Precision Medicine Based Approach
With a desire of investigators to utilize specific groups of PEGS participants, the PEGS is well poised to take advantage of a personalized/precision medicine approach for future studies. Precision medicine grew out of a 2011 National Research Council (NRC) publication, Toward Precision Medicine which proposed an Information Commons of data collection (an individual s exposome, signs and symptoms, genome, epigenome, microbiome, and other types of patient data) as the basis of a transformative paradigm in individual health care that per the NRC would lead to more accurate diagnosis, more targeted treatments, and ultimately improved clinical outcomes. The NIH s Precision Medicine Initiative, now the All of US Research Program, was one of two national programs (the other being the Precision Medicine Initiative for Oncology) to focus on bringing this vision to fruition. All of Us is described as a participant- engaged, data-driven enterprise supporting research at the intersection of human biology, behavior, genetics, environment, data science, computation and much more to produce new knowledge with the goal of developing more effective ways to treat disease with the goal of enrolling 1 million participants nationwide. The PEGS, over the last few years, has been building the infrastructure and pursuing the goal of similarly merging data regarding an individual s genome, exposome, epigenome, microbiome, and electronic health records (EHR) to examine gene-environment interactions in health and disease.
Examples of PEGS with Personalized/Precision Medicine Based Approach
The PEGS has begun collaborating with individuals involved in the NCATS funded Biomedical Data Translator Program (Translator) which is an initiative to develop a comprehensive, relational, N-dimensional Biomedical Data Translator that integrates multiple types of existing data sources, including objective signs and symptoms of disease, drug effects, and intervening types of biological data relevant to understanding pathophysiology. One illustrative use-case of the Translator demonstrates the potential of a precision medicine approach examining individual s gene environment and clinical data that integrates research surrounding a rare group of participants and a larger cohort. Drs. Maureen Hoatlin and Melissa Haendel of the Oregon Health and Science University are integrating through developed ontology, data from patients with Fanconi Anemia (a rare hereditary disorder with defective DNA damage response and repair) with those with deficient aldehyde processing (540 million people worldwide are deficient in acetaldehyde dehydrogenase 2 (ALDH2) activity through a single polymorphism,
which can manifest as Asian Flushing Syndrome with alcohol consumption). Fanconi anemia patients with polymorphisms in ALDH2 have accelerated progression of bone marrow failure as do those with idiopathic aplastic anemia. Individuals with the alcohol flushing response are also at an elevated risk of squamous cell esophageal cancer from alcohol consumption and may be at heightened risk of other pathologies. The Oregon Translator use-case project is exploring through genomic, environmental, and clinical database integration how other aldehyde gene variants modify the Fanconi anemia phenotype and how exposures in general affect those with ALDH2 variants compared to those without variants. A collaborator of the Oregon Translator project, Dr. Peter Robinson of the Jackson Laboratory for Genomic Medicine who is heading the Monarch Initiative, which developed the Human Phenotype Ontology, a vocabulary to describe human disease features (phenotypes), is interested in using the PEGS Exposome Survey data as part of his effort to develop a similar ontology for exposures. Because of the overlap between PEGS and UNC participants [at least approximately 6,000; data from the UNC affiliated Renaissance Computing Institute (RENCI) unpublished], the PEGS is working with members of the Translator teams to collaborate on existing use-case scenarios including one with Dr. Ashok Krishnamurthy at UNC which is examining the asthma-like phenotype (clinically observable signs and symptoms and characteristic test results) in the context of an asthma endotype [biomarkers, biological pathways, genetic background, and (socio)environmental exposures]. The Translator collaborations are just one illustrating how the PEGS could use a precision medicine-type of approach.
Another example of a collaborative efforts that uses small precision medicine accessible populations within the PEGS is in the examination of the microbiome. In collaboration with Dr. Stavros Garantziotis, PEGS asthmatic participants with a polymorphism in the TLR5 gene are having their microbiome examined in comparison with controls. High impact papers have recently found microbiome correlations with several small disease cohorts including Alzheimer s disease (using 25 Alzheimer s patients), posttraumatic stress disorder (using 18 posttraumatic stress disorder patients), and dPEGSession (using 44 irritable bowel syndrome patients). Similar precision medicine driven studies can be used involving epigenomic and exposome factors, such as PEGS black cohosh using participants. The PEGS plans to utilize specific groups including arhinia participants, hypothalamic amenorrhea participants, and other more specific groups involving pediatric participant, and groups from the NIH Clinical Center in the near future to uniquely address gene-environmental interactions in unique populations that may have broader implications. Enriching for these types of specific groups will make the PEGS even more valuable as a resource both at the NIEHS and with extramural collaborators.
PEGS Aim 2: PEGS as a Resource for both Intramural and Extramural Investigators through Collaborations and Providing Accessible Databases
PEGS Existing Databases
The PEGS has a Master Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Database to facilitate rapid access to genotype data on PEGS participants. Prior to creation of the database, genotype readings had been stored in individual files (one per SNP), with individual files for specific investigator projects. This arrangement flowed out of the above-mentioned PEGS Consortium Project in which multiple investigators collectively identified over 600 SNPs from candidate genes in a range of diseases approximately 3,700 PEGS participants were then genotyped on those 600+ SNPs. Investigators could receive their specified SNP files from the set. Over time, however, additional SNPs and PEGS participants have been genotyped, generating yet more files. It is not infrequent to combine newer and older readings, and to join these with phenotypic data now available from the Health and Exposure Survey and the Exposome Survey. Also, investigators sometimes have an interest sharing their SNPs sets in collaborative efforts. The Master SNP Database supports these needs by aggregating all genotypes in one SAS dataset making it easy to select any combination of SNPs desired for a given analysis.
The PEGS is using REDCap (Research Electronic Data Capture) for a Core Medical History Form obtained on participants seen in the NIEHS Clinical Research Unit and future administration of the Health and Exposure Survey. REDCap is a secure web application for building and managing online surveys and databases.
Information is made available to internal and external investigators through a review process. Additional information when obtained, may be placed into public facing databases, such as DbGAP for whole genome sequencing data, when available.
Electronic Health Records
A personalized/precision medicine based approach requires data from many sources from individual participants to enhance the effectiveness of translational research, including clinical data. To facilitate this approach, the PEGS will obtain electronic health record (EHR) data from a number of collaborating institutions.
Data from UNC will be obtained in collaboration with the North Carolina Translational and Clinical Sciences (TraCS) Institute at UNC. This will ultimately allow the PEGS to link and analyze UNC EHR data with PEGS study data for the estimated 6,000 PEGS participants with UNC records (information from RENCI). The ongoing collaboration began with a use case (described in Examples of PEGS with Personalized/Precision Medicine Based Approach) which may also involve the UNC Translator use case project examining asthma.
The PEGS will also obtain EHR data through an ongoing collaboration with Duke University. The size of the overlapping Duke-PEGS population is being determined as a first step in the collaboration. Characterization of this overlap will inform the strategy and prioritization of EHR
sharing. When the PEGS obtains Duke EHR data, it will be linked and analyzed with PEGS study data.
UNC and Duke are part of the Carolina Collaborative, a consortium of Health Sciences South Carolina and four Clinical and Translational Science Awards (CTSA) programs that also includes Medical University of South Carolina, UNC and Wake Forest University, which is a data resource that harmonizes the EHR data of these institutions to expedite clinical research and quality improvement. The PEGS is engaged in talks with members of the Collaborative to similarly gain access to EHRs for overlap participants with other medical systems.
Whole Genome / Whole Exome Sequencing
In pursuit of the best utilization of a precision based medicine approach to environmental health translational research and pivotal to examining gene-environment interactions in health and disease, the PEGS will extensively genotype the DNA of approximately 9,000 PEGS participant through a combination of whole genome sequencing, whole exome sequencing, and SNP arrays with imputation. Besides having value in specific groups of interest, sequencing healthy controls may have research benefits beyond polymorphism associated research. As part of the MedSeq project, 50 generally healthy adults were sequenced. Eleven of the 50 had variants of rare diseases, though only two showed demonstrable signs of disease. One had a variant for fundus albipunctatus with poor night vision and the other a variant for variegate porphyria, a condition that manifests as sunlight sensitivity and reactions to certain medications. However, every individual in the MedSeq study had at least one recessive carrier gene linked to certain conditions. Importantly, PEGS participants with actionable variants of pathological genes will have genetic counseling made available to them through NHGRI, once the variations are confirmed by a CLIA certified laboratory by NHGRI. Studies of individuals in the PEGS in the context of specific disease groups, exposure groups, or as healthy groups in conjunction with other precision medicine information will greatly enhance the PEGS s ability to answer environmental health translational research questions.
Sequencing data on PEGS participants will be placed into DbGAP and individual level information will be made available to investigators through a yet to be determined process. Data will be also stored at NIEHS to facilitate analysis.
PEGS Collaborations
In addition to providing resources which investigators can independently use after a review process through the PEGS Internal Advisory Committee (IAC)/PEGS Principal Investigator (PI), the PEGS seeks both intramural and extramural collaborations. Examples extramurally include the aforementioned Translator UNC asthma use case scenario, using the PEGS Exposome Survey data to develop a human exposure ontology, linking PEGS data with UNC EHRs in collaboration with TraCS, and genotyping, sample selection, and data analysis for external investigators through the PEGS laboratory. In addition, the PEGS is in talks with the All of Us research program to make the Exposome available for their planned Precision Medicine Initiative cohort. Intramural collaboration examples include the above-mentioned microbiome collaborative study, and numerous genotype-phenotype correlation studies where genotyping, statistical analysis are provided by the PEGS laboratory in conjunction with study planning and conclusion determination in collaboration with the investigator.
To facilitate collaborations, the PEGS is also part of the recently formed The Genomic Ascertainment Cohort (TGAC). This will be a super-cohort of at least 10,000 research
participants who have undergone exome or genome sequencing, and who are available for post- sequencing phenotyping in order to facilitate predictive genomic medicine studies at NIH. Participating individuals will be consented in a way that data can be shared and subjects recalled to answer additional questions beyond those of the original study.
Contributors to the super-cohort include the PEGS, the NIH ClinSeq cohort, the Inova Translational Medicine Institute, intramural NIH investigators who have a group of >= 100 research participants who are consented for sequencing and genotyping, and others when deemed appropriate by the project oversight committee.
To further facilitate collaborations, PEGS is joining with the Coronavirus Pandemic Epidemiology (COPE) Consortium, headed by the Mongan Institute at Massachusetts General Hospital, to assist in understanding COVID-19 symptoms, engage in a comprehensive assessment of COVID-19 risk factors, and understand the long-term health factors from the pandemic. PEGS is interested in advancing COVID-19 research by utilizing its large active research cohort with a repository containing health and environmental exposure data. This data is useful in understanding how COVID-19 infection affects a range of health outcomes.
Additionally, understanding the broad impacts of COVID-19 are key to correctly interpreting future exposure-disease relationships.
In the initial phase of collaboration, PEGS encourages participants to sign up for the consortium s COVID Symptom Study App, developed by King s College and Zoe Global, Ltd. Participants can choose to input their symptoms in the daily symptom tracker, which integrates symptom data with participant information collected by the app. Eventually, PEGS will integrate PEGS participants consortium data with their PEGS data. PEGS will receive data including, but not limited to, exposures, symptoms, and outcomes from the COVID Symptom Study App. Any analysis of this data would be submitted as a separate protocol to the IRB for approval. Neither NIH nor NIEHS owns or operates the app, nor did PEGS have any involvement in its development. PEGS does not endorse this app and are not responsible for the accuracy of content or terms in this application s privacy policy.
PEGS Aim 3: PEGS as a Longitudinal Study
Exposures begin in utero and epigenetic changes are crucial to the developing embryo. Life course studies have shown that early life environmental processes influence adult function and the likelihood to acquire chronic diseases later in life. Chronic diseases are a result of more than an individual s genetic variants and are most likely a result of environmental and behavioral stressors interacting with genetic predisposition. Cross-sectional studies have limitations
in detecting gene-environment interactions while longitudinal and prospective cohort
studies can characterize exposures and risk factors before disease onset, therefore reducing some of the common biases of case-control studies and the assessment of environmental risk factors. As a case and point, individuals who grew up during World War 1 would be expected to have different exposures and lived under different circumstances than those who grew up during the Great Depression, the Green Revolution of the late 60s early 70s, or the present. In addition, with the necessity of keeping health and exposure data up to date to match other precision based medicine data, it is imperative to repeat measurements of PEGS participants throughout their life course. To this end, the PEGS has begun pediatric recruitment which is a valuable asset not just to the PEGS but investigators interested in pediatric research associated questions.
Questionnaires developed by the PEGS are now available in electronic form and can be easily re- administered to participants, which is crucial for obtaining follow-up health and disease information that follows participants as they age and are likely to develop diseases, and also for tracking their exposures across a lifetime. Questionnaires available for longitudinal analysis include the PEGS Health and Exposure Survey and the PEGS Exposome Survey, in addition to investigator developed questionnaires. Also, PEGS has developed the infrastructure for obtaining repeat blood samples or saliva samples. This is important for gathering biospecimens for analysis of epigenetic changes that may have occurred after significant exposures or length of time. Similarly, microbiome sampling may be conducted in a longitudinal manner.

arm_group.description: Specimens are available to investigators in coded form to anonymously screen for the presence of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and other mutations in DNA.

study_pop.textblock: Convenience sample from the general population.

criteria.textblock:
- INCLUSION AND EXCLUSION CRITERIA:
- Non-Pregnant adults (greater than or equal to 18 years of age) or minors (ages 8-17 years old) are eligible to enroll in the Environmental Polymorphisms Registry.
- Participants must be able to understand and provide written informed consent (adult participants or parent/ guardian of minors) and assent (minors) to participate.
- Women who self-report that they are currently pregnant will be excluded from eligibility. A pregnancy test will only be done if the PI feels it is indicated.
There are no other inclusion or exclusion criteria.

overall_official.affiliation: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS)
